posts.body: asdfasfdsafdsfsdafdsafds

== Note to anyone running the fixed code ==
content.json needs to change after ZeroID was activated for you to be able to post

>>a7c8090f-4836-44f8-bc66-571862cfe048
You gotta give up them sticks.

>>0a34ad04-0992-4d75-b34a-3a4fb443d436
Install a fresh ZeroNet on another folder and copy the file over to the hacked install. The contents.js file I mean is in the 1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D directory, not the one that is in the users folder (that one should be updated automatically). You could also remove the read only property of the one in 1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D and it should be updated too, but I haven't tried that.

== Is there any problem with ZeroID? ==
Yes, there are some issues with it.
- The service is based on IP based rate-limiting. This means that if you access it through, say, Firefox, it will leak your clearnet IP to a centralized server. And if you access it with Tor Browser, it might be very difficult to actually get a certificate if other Tor users are also trying to get one.
- Because it's based on IP rate limiting, it offers a single point of failure. If somebody wanted to prevent '''new''' users from joining the board (at least to post) all they'd need to do is to DDoS ZeroID's servers. The catch is they'd be shutting down every other Zeronet site that uses ZeroID, but considering 08chan is the biggest ZeroNet site so far, I don't think they'll care too much about that collateral damage.

== Is there another way of rate-limiting the creation of new user certificates? ==
-'''Yes.''' It's called a "proof of work" (PoW). The way it works is having the user do something that takes a lot of cycles to solve, but can be checked very fast. The main way to do this is by asking the user to find crack a hash.
- There are two main brands of PoW hashes: those designed to require a GPU to use (because they'd be unbearably slow on a CPU) and those designed to reduce the advantage a GPU has when computing it.
- If you use a CPU based one then everyone could compute a hash in a reasonable amount of time.
- If you use a GPU based one (like the one used in Bitcoin) then some people with weak GPUs couldn't. You can have a server similar to ZeroID that computes it for them, but nodody's going to set aside a $500 GPU aside just for a chink cartoon board, and it'd be similarly vulnerable to DDoS. So better to go with a CPU based one.

== How can this rate-limiting be implemented on Zeronet? ==
Clients could be made to require other clients to have one special (invisible in the GUI) post or file providing the PoW, which is then scanned and verified before accepting any additional data from that user.

== Can a decentralized captcha ever be implemented? ==
Yes, at least in theory. You could make one user's computer generate a packet of data with
-the captcha (an image)
-the hash of the text in it (the solution) and
-the ID intended target user
-and digital signature of the packet
Then all machines on the network require each poster to provide the packet mentioned above + the cleartext text on the picture (the solution), and don't accept the post until a valid pair of (packet,solution) is provided.

== Is there any issue with this? ==
'''Yes.''' The problem is that for this to work effectively, two certificates need to correspond to actually two physically different people. Otherwise the spammer can just provide himself the solution from the instance that generated the captcha.
The main way I see to mitigate this is that each client keeps track of either
- How long a given user has been active
- How many posts has he made
- How much data has the user seeded over it's lifetime
And only accepts captchas generated by users that have one of those features high enough to be considered a trusted user.
The way these values could be known is that when every user receives, say, 50MB of data, it signs a certificate as a gift to the seeder, which when collected to a certain amount become the way for a user to prove he can be trusted with generating captchas and not give out the solution to the spammer.
This also can be combined with rate limiting in the generation of certs, either PoW or centralized (ZeroID or others).

== Is there any problem with ZeroID? ==
Yes, there are some issues with it.
- The service is based on IP based rate-limiting. This means that if you access it through, say, Firefox, it will leak your clearnet IP to a centralized server. And if you access it with Tor Browser, it might be very difficult to actually get a certificate if other Tor users are also trying to get one.
- Because it's based on IP rate limiting, it offers a single point of failure. If somebody wanted to prevent '''new''' users from joining the board (at least to post) all they'd need to do is to DDoS ZeroID's servers. The catch is they'd be shutting down every other Zeronet site that uses ZeroID, but considering 08chan is the biggest ZeroNet site so far, I don't think they'll care too much about that collateral damage.

== Is there another way of rate-limiting the creation of new user certificates? ==
-'''Yes.''' It's called a "proof of work" (PoW). The way it works is having the user do something that takes a lot of cycles to solve, but can be checked very fast. The main way to do this is by asking the user to find crack a hash.
- There are two main brands of PoW hashes: those designed to require a GPU to use (because they'd be unbearably slow on a CPU) and those designed to reduce the advantage a GPU has when computing it.
- If you use a CPU based one then everyone could compute a hash in a reasonable amount of time.
- If you use a GPU based one (like the one used in Bitcoin) then some people with weak GPUs couldn't. You can have a server similar to ZeroID that computes it for them, but nodody's going to set aside a $500 GPU aside just for a chink cartoon board, and it'd be similarly vulnerable to DDoS. So better to go with a CPU based one.

== How can this rate-limiting be implemented on Zeronet? ==
Clients could be made to require other clients to have one special (invisible in the GUI) post or file providing the PoW, which is then scanned and verified before accepting any additional data from that user.

== Can a decentralized captcha ever be implemented? ==
Yes, at least in theory. You could make one user's computer generate a packet of data with
-the captcha (an image)
-the hash of the text in it (the solution) and
-the ID intended target user
-and digital signature of the packet
Then all machines on the network require each poster to provide the packet mentioned above + the cleartext text on the picture (the solution), and don't accept the post until a valid pair of (packet,solution) is provided.

== Is there any issue with this? ==
'''Yes.''' The problem is that for this to work effectively, two certificates need to correspond to actually two physically different people. Otherwise the spammer can just provide himself the solution from the instance that generated the captcha.
The main way I see to mitigate this is that each client keeps track of either
- How long a given user has been active
- How many posts has he made
- How much data has the user seeded over it's lifetime
And only accepts captchas generated by users that have one of those features high enough to be considered a trusted user.
The way these values could be known is that when every user receives, say, 50MB of data, it signs a certificate as a gift to the seeder, which when collected to a certain amount become the way for a user to prove he can be trusted with generating captchas and not give out the solution to the spammer.
This also can be combined with rate limiting in the generation of certs, either PoW or centralized (ZeroID or others).

**Removing the names from the DOM so they can't be found using element inspector would likely require changing the templates for the site which you could also do yourself, but I don't know how to do it.**

>>aa8ff392-866d-4d81-b3eb-697f3e3ceabb
There was an anon who posted a screenshot of IPs from a data management agency appearing as peers to his client.
Looks like they began data harvesting IPs mere hours after 8ch.net was shut down. Well, all you require is to fire up a client and set Wireshark to record all the packets, and you can analyze the data later. So it makes sense that we began to be monitored early on.
Also, you forgot to include some of the juiciest bits.
>ZeroNet works the same way, a fact that’s been much-discussed on the new site. For that reason, ZeroNet integrates tightly with Tor, an anonymity system that places layers of cut-out addresses between a user and the websites they visit. But only 41 percent of 08chan’s users’ are using Tor, based on our analysis of the peer-to-peer traffic at the site.
>Users on 08chan have been complaining that the site is buggy and slow over Tor, and the site’s own administrator initially encouraged anons to just connect directly. “Feel free to post without Tor,” he wrote in a welcome message. “Even as the admin I have no power to identify anyone.”
>Though an IP address alone doesn’t identify the person behind it, it can nonetheless be telling, particularly when a user is running websites or other services off the same IP, as dozens in our sample were. One anon in Georgia runs an open file-sharing server from home. The server’s banner message: “Hitler did nothing wrong.”
Priceless.

>[laughs in dynamic IP]
Cops can get your ID from a dynamic IP if they know when it was collected.
>Also, who cares? All they can prove is that you have visited 08chan and have Zeronet running.
If they have a good datamining setup they can also know:
-What your client is sharing.
-To some extent, what threads you visited, especially if you didn't click "download and distribute all files" and/or your data folder is still small.
-Your ID at the time of collection, if they happened to be one of the guys you pushed your message to. **I'm not actually sure about this one. Maybe if they had a lot of compute and network bandwidth they could distinguish whether any given new message they received was a new post or just being distributed by the network by analyzing how fast it spreads, since it'd spread exponentially faster the further down the distribution chain because of more peers seeding it.**
>>71374d2f-ff59-47d4-a39c-e142e0c8f93a
>The problem, as I understand it is that IPs can only be linked because of seeding (this is P2P after all), but they cannot link anyone to a particular post, thanks to certificates. 
That seems to be possible, but I'm not sure it's the case.
If posts are sent so fast as they are, that can't be just through other clients polling yours, it must be pushed in some way, right? Are all messages distributed through pushing?
How does my client know when it has a message yours doesn't? File hashes?
>This is why the admin needs to adapt the system so that we can use self signed certs but also minimize spam bots.
I don't follow. How does ZeroID allow them to link posts with IPs? **Other than you connecting to ZeroID initially to get the cert**

>>6eb5a7c4-5a4f-4a19-b57b-d99c747f229b
People with shitbox computers can't browse the site already.
I know, I've tried with a shitty 2GB laptop. The site then becomes an unusable javascript mess.
The difference in single core performance is different  by a factor of at most 4 or 5 times between the slowest shitbox being able to browse here and top of the line. The problem then becomes preventing parallelism for generating a single ID (which is important also to remove a GPU's advantage, since an average GPU has like 5 code fetching units IIRC that are conceptually equivalent to a CPU core each, and goes up into the dozens per chip).
I think there are algorithms designed for that, though. In any case I don't think PoW alone is a better solution than ZeroID. It'd only be more useful when combined with everything else.
In any case, you can always set up a hidden service website that upon completing a captcha does the PoW challenge for you and gives you the cert to install it on your machine.
bump

>>ca264716-1d86-453e-b7de-28d4130fe69d
You can already. Just modify the CSS to set display:none on all elements of class post-name and set the read only property on the file so it doesn't get overwritten.

>>70fcdb25-88c5-4800-8a21-cefc7e93caa3

Setting Tor to "Always" in the settings and always using Tor Browser is the bare minimum. Anything less than that is bullshit.

>>25b1bd99-7a9d-4d4f-b06e-e91f6e845421
Where are they in Millchan's source code?

>>3666eb09-976d-46ae-8e88-81bdddc90e04
You mean by default on the latest Millchan version? You'd have to talk with the Millchan devs, but I don't think they're going to hide ZeroIDs just because of somebody asking nicely.

>>628d3e61-d633-42bf-a8ea-e9aa212455dc

Just look at Codemonkey's twatter page.
All the QBoomers are freaking out because 08chan wasn't developed by 8chan's owner.

>>b917452e-aa1c-4c52-b299-e2aa8aa18ea0
Nice try, glower.
All the clients connect to each other through .onion by default, and anyone who has Tor disabled doesn't seed to Tor users anyway.
It would be perfectly usable with everyone using Tor.

>>74d89874-d9e3-4105-86cf-41bf416432e5
Why do you say half the posts disappeared?
I lost 5GB of data somehow, was it because of that?
Edit: nevermind, I found out what you mean, and the 5gb lost couldn't have been because of it.

>>a0bcff1b-987e-4338-ad9b-e1f0cf8c7d7e
>Explain to me in what way tor is superior to this then.
Tor implements onion routing. It means if at least one of the nodes in your route is actually anonymizing traffic (aka doesn't keep logs and give them to the authorities) then you are anonymous (for the most part, correlation attacks and all that).
>I dont trust the tor network at all
That's fine, I don't either. I just trust it more than corporate entities promising not to sell my data or give it away to the FBI to avoid legal pressure from the FBI and the associated lawyer fees.
>and ive found it to be completely redundant in any case.
Why?
>The only point of failure here is your VPN provider
In your setup? Maybe (ignoring that most VPN clients leak data by default to the clearnet).
But then again I could say that in Tor the only point of failure is the Tor network. And I trust it more than I do some random company.
>you can run all of your internet activity on Tails if you want, but youre wasting your time.
I don't go that far, and you don't need to either. I won't disclose my OS unnecessarily, but I don't use Tails.
>A lot of this isnt necessarily applicable to zeronet either due to the way zeronet works, this is a general browsing guide for the most part. 
VPNs are useless for general browsing as well as for ZeroNet.
>I would not trust zeronet on Tor if i didnt have a VPN behind it, and I dont trust TOR to begin with
You can trust ZeroNet to give away your IP when using without Tor. It's just the way it works. In fact ZeroNet lowers Tor's effectiveness when using it with it because of patterns in the availability of data packets, but for the most part that's unavoidable in p2p networks.

>>15707c57-e399-43e4-99dd-4b67f3a3643a
>This is for you then. Ill show you how to route zeronet activity through tor without using the tor browser.
Nice try. Now I'm almost completely sure you're a glownigger.
If you don't use Tor Browser, you aren't anonymous AT ALL.
All a zite has to do to de-anonymize you is to ping a clearnet IP with your ID. Bam, the feds have your IP and everything you ever posted with that ID.

>>4d3b5d3a-ed26-4418-9a5f-c2ec80ef36c0
Yes, I admit I was wrong. Clients probably do prioritize clearnet to p2p between one another by default.
And yes, clearnet is faster. But the speed is not worth it.
Even if we needed to only post text to make it work with Tor (we don't) it would still be better than using clearnet pozz.
In any case, the main problem with seeding is people post shit and then turn off their PCs. Everybody should leave their clients and the web interface open as long as possible (IIRC somebody in another thread found out without having the interface open the Zeronet service doesn't seed by itself for whatever reason).

>>2fb61210-3fcf-47d5-98bc-c0aab1320b16
>yes
When hashes differ, how does it know which of the two clients has the latest version of a file?

>>91ca4d65-4a2f-44e2-87c0-9a4373c25e5f
Driver's ID. **I mean your name and address**

>>a8a22d3f-53bd-4d41-828c-2b4e9fb7607f
>Cop can not know if the IP is a initial seeder (author of a post) or just any peer.
They can (probabilistically), but they need a few servers constantly polling the network.
If a certain post they received wasn't had by any other peer at the moment they received it, there's a high chance they connected to the initial seeder's IP, so that IP is associated to the identity in a database.
If the association pops up two or three times in the database, you can almost be sure it wasn't a false positive and the IP does indeed correspond to that ID.

>>736e0997-09cb-41a7-90b7-9e0ca51893cd
>bunch of irrelevant bullshit
Ok. How does that change anything I've said?
The javascript in your browser that is part of a zite can ignore Zeronet and connect to clearnet IPs. This is the way the ZeroID delivering zite works. What is so hard to understand about that?
>>2fac011e-f953-46ff-ab63-051e5f682b01
So basically you tell me
>here, use this to hide your IP with Tor ;-)
and when I tell you it doesn't work, you tell me
>oh well, should've used a VPN then :^)
?
Fuck off.
>>2fac011e-f953-46ff-ab63-051e5f682b01
>Tor browser hides your online fingerprint (lazily)
Better than your solution does.
Pro tip: dynamic zites REQUIRE javascript to work. So you didn't even try what you outlined in the OP.
And you didn't even mention anything about Canvas fingerprinting.
Pro tip: vising the FSF's Panopticlick with your jerry rigged anti-fingerprint solution and it'll tell you all the ways in which it sucks.
>and it protects your ip address.
Yes, that's the point.
>I just showed you how to protect your online fingerprint (effectively)
No, you showed how to try to do it ineffectively.
>and a good vpn protects your ip even better than the TOR network.
No it doesn't lmao. All the IPs passing through a VPN are probably funneled directly to the NSA, and that's even if the owners aren't selling the data, because the intel agencies are bound to deploy agents in the field passing off as potential employees to be hired and sabotage their operations.

>>ad229f96-4b1a-4e79-a99e-4b52d8a35c5e
>A possible weakness of this is certificate farming, we need some kind of limit to the lifetime of ID's.
Good point. Otherwise the couldn't hit us all the time, but when they do, they could hit us hard.

>>90207dc2-e913-4d17-859c-5370f6b9e092
Well, I think he's wrong.
First off, spammers don't necessarily have a lot of CPU and GPU power. That shit takes money.
And if they '''do''' have money, then they also have lots of IPs and pajeets to solve captchas for them. Yet clearnet sites with IP bans and captchas rarely get a lot of spam.
Spammers are out there to take the low hanging fruit. They won't bother to run a server outfitted with four Titan Vs just to spam one post a minute.
And in any case, algorithms can be engineered to work better on CPUs than they do in GPUs or FPGAs.

>>a1c45227-2791-461e-9558-fa45f6aeb353
>That would be very convenient, seeing as you cannot decide who you are peering with
Why not? Does the protocol not allow that? **Do you have proof?**
>I'm pretty sure there are anons who have posted that haven't seeded from each other at all despite being a regular user.
They can run VMs on multiple  server racks until they have everyone as a peer on one of the VMs at any given time. The NSA has trillions of dollars to play with.

>>6cd1c674-2cef-476e-a523-c50f68c363dc
>Simultaneously, 08chan is immune to bad board moderation. 
It's not. The BOs can blacklist posts and 99% of people won't ever see those posts.

>>51493a60-81a5-4c89-b7f2-00e6ae7471f5
Well I wouldn't hold my breath. Almost all if not all the possible solutions to spam involve hard-to-generate certificates.
I mean, right now you can switch identities, you just have to spam the ZeroID site's "new ID" button until it gives you a new cert. **it'll be faster if you switch IPs and clear your browser's data before accessing it again**

>>fdc859cf-995d-4569-8ed5-6866b6af21fb
>edit: its covered in the about:config link,
Fair enough, I missed that.
>every tor confiuration is there.
Sure, but Tor Browser makes changes to the C++ source code too.
>TOR browser is frefox you brainlet, its just shitty NSA firefox
Oh, so you're one of the /pol/niggers who think Tor is a honeypot. Well, **it might be,** but Tor browser includes source patches to Firefox to prevent things like DNS leaks, it's not just an about:config hack.
>>fdc859cf-995d-4569-8ed5-6866b6af21fb
>Im only explaining to you how things work.
No, I am. If you decide to ignore the fact that the js on a zite can connect to clearnet IPs and imply I don't know what I'm talking about then go ahead I guess. Anons that see this thread can make their own decisions, I don't give a fuck.
>>f3e3e798-4f78-4eff-a8ed-4551631267e4
>I'm left with no arguments, so I'll just post drawings
Ok...

>>303b6709-75b7-4451-880e-c4efea19139d
Sounds like your content.json is read only.
Try right clicking on it and remove the read only property.
Edit: if that's not it then just re-install Zeronet and move over all the user directories in the users folder, and rebuild the database (button is on the sidebar to the right).

>>1238a1a0-6b37-4acd-a645-779784fbb821
>is either lost or needs to be seeded again. 
I think it actually needs to be re-published. The previous posts can't be seeded as they are because they aren't signed with a valid ZeroID cert.

== Attention ==
When the site switches to ZeroID mode, all the previous content is lost if the site doesn't switch back, because it can't be seeded as it doesn't have a valid ZeroID cert. Just sayin.
We can only see it because we had it downloaded before the switch.

>>9d26bce9-4f64-4ec5-b73a-e629ca205ceb
Dude, it doesn't matter how ZeroNet works wrt this. Once ZeroNet delivers an HTML document with javascript to your browser, the javascript on it can do whatever the fuck it wants as long as the browser offers an API to do it. Which includes using XMLHttpRequest to ping '''any''' IP that includes 127.0.0.1 as a source in its CORS. And the browser will send that request through the regular Internet, because as you yourself said, the browser doesn't know about ZeroNet, it just knows a page it accessed at 127.0.0.1 wants to make an HTTPS connection to a certain IP.

>>9d26bce9-4f64-4ec5-b73a-e629ca205ceb
>Tor is absolutely a honeypot
And you know this for certain, how? Because it was originally developed by the navy? It was developed (at least in theory) so the agents could use it to perform intelligence and counter-intelligence online, which they still do. That doesn't mean it doesn't work for anonymity.
>but thats fine because VPNs arent
And you know that, how? Because the CEO told you it isn't?

>>9393c7d8-ebdf-4836-a053-9a461ec17227
>What youre saying is also true when youre using tor browser anyway
No, it isn't. When the browser is configured to use Tor as a proxy, and has its code patched to prevent any traffic at all (like DNS leaks) from going outside that proxy, then all the IP traffic is router through Tor, whether it's directed to an .onion or to an IP.
There still might be a bug that allows traffic to not go through the proxy (this is also true for VPN software btw, and probably more common there), and that’s why operating system level and VM level solutions like Tails, Whonix and Qubes were developed.
Too bad nobody has bothered to develop these for VPNs. Hmm, I wonder why. 
>they recommend you only visit .onion sites through the browser
No they don't lol. Show me where they say this.
They recommend you don't send sensitive data unencrypted to the clearnet, because then the exit node can see it. Which is true for VPNs too.
>because its essentially useless software for protecting your privacy outside of the .onion network.
Not, it isn't. Tor was developed to browse the Internet first, .onions were developed afterward to provide a way of hosting sites using Tor.
You're so ignorant about all of this it hurts.

>>09d90627-495b-4a3d-a979-b68b50d0778a
>They'll probably give you less information than the ZeroID that's now required
Not if you're LE. If they know the approximate time the IP was recorded, they can call up the ISP and ask them to tell them the person who had that IP assigned at that moment in time. ISPs keep track of that stuff precisely for that reason.

>>d6b84f0f-c9ca-4ef7-a5db-a35efa412abd
>Well we've come full circle here, your browsers proxy configuration doesnt matter because youre not sending data out through your browser, youre sending it through your computer.
It matters because in one case the receiving computer will receive whatever the jew decides to send in plaintext (which includes your Zeronet ID, CP, or whatever the creator of the zite wants it to be) and in the other all the receiving computer will see is a stream of encrypted data which he must send to another randomly picked machine in the Tor network.
>On that subject, I also run a proxy, it forces all of my network traffic through my vpn network and protects my dns on a system level, a level appropriate for Zeronet
Good for you.
>this is also all irrelevent, because when I start TOR in the background, when it opens a connection to the tor network, it also routes all activity through a proxy, whichis clearly visible in the logs upon runnin zeronet.py
Prove it. Show me where it sends your activity through a proxy (that's not one you have configured yourself to send traffic to).
I've sniffed the packets and all that ZeroNet is sending is peer requests to the tracker (because I choose it that way, you can choose to route peer requests to the trackers through Tor too) and p2p traffic to relay through Tor.
>EDIT: this is why you open localhost 127.0.1 in your proxy configuration on tor browser.
No, you open 127.0.0.1 to be able to access the pages provided by the ZeroNet server.
>That excludes yourself from tor.
It only does for requests going to 127.0.0.1. Requests going to any other IP are still going to be routed through Tor.

>>e987be3d-0e0f-4def-bf7f-50ef96280576
>>9cfada95-19ee-46d2-9555-ab13b7cc4a2c
It was bound to happen sooner or later.
At least the switch to ZeroID was early enough that not too much valuable content was lost.

>>a9eab554-9cb1-4d7d-801d-c0d535462835
>practicaly setting up an own CA and creating a new signature for the old posts
Oh, you meant modifying each user's content.json to add a valid signature? Any ideas on how to do that? Good thinking, that might be possible by pushing a js update. But I don't know if the ZeroNet API allows you to do that (it would require arbitrary filesystem access inside your zite's data directory unless there's some more specific method in the API).
If it's possible then you don't need your own CA, you would just need to create a single ZeroID and slap it on each user's content.json.

>>7b6d3565-69c1-4308-b550-d30d659e94bc
>No, it looks like you can only blacklist (i.e. ban), not whitelist.
Does ZeroID run at the ZeroNet or at the zite level? If it's the later it could be patched to allow whitelisting, if not then I guess not.
>Not so fast. You can't get get a zeroid with arbitrary auth_address (the world would burn down in a chaos in 5 minutes if you'd find a way to do it) and since they're used as user id's in millchan, you don't want to change them either.
>I didn't intend to do it as a js change, just put the modified files into my zeronet client and let it distribute. The other clients would accept them since they have a valid signature.
You mean create a new CA that can sign already existing auth_address? Is auth_address the same as the user address (what's in the user folder names)?
What files in particular would you modify to get the clients to recognize this new CA authority as valid? Isn't that baked into ZeroNet? Or does the API allow you to make it recognize new ones?
With js you could move every user's file into the same ZeroID folder, and then combine all the data.json files into one, and create a content.json for it. Would probably take less than one minute to run the script. Then anyone that already has the files will seed them as if they were from the very beginning.
Of course there are some problems with this approach, mainly blacklisting killing everything since everything would be posted by the same user.

== /ALPR/ GENERAL 0.2 (zeronet mirror) ==
I created a thread on /cy/ as well, mistaking the single users multiple posts as organic content. I can maintain two threads I think. We'll see. I'll be posting proposes solutions here as well.

<LET'S DO SOME INFOSEC WORK SHAZBOTS

This is a new series I am going to make based on the products collectively known as Automatic License Plate Readers (aka ALPRs). There is a lot of mystery and myth surrounding this technology as well as methods of effectively evading it, if any exist at all. Collectively I am confident we can find a solution to the Automated threat

>inb4 if you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear

Fuck you.

>What is it?

"Typically, ALPR systems are comprised of high-speed cameras connected to computers that photograph every license plate that passes. The photo is converted to letters and numbers, which are attached to a time and location stamp, then uploaded to a central server. This allows police to identify and record the locations of vehicles in real time and also identify where those vehicles have been in the past. Using this information, police could establish driving patterns for individual cars. The type of data ALPRs collect, analyze, and access often depends on what kind of systems they use and how they combine the data."

https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/04/four-flavors-automated-license-plate-reader-technology

( https://web.archive.org/web/20190705211401/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/04/four-flavors-automated-license-plate-reader-technology )

>Why the concern?

Much like Stringrays (cell towerspoofing MITM devices used by LEO) a few years back, these devices are essentially unregulated. When used by private parties have been they have been able to scan up to 8k license plates in a single day, according to only one study. These databases are up for sale, much like cell location data. The data recorded includes GPS location, scan coordinates, and timestamp. When factoring in this information and without even the consideration of data breaches this clearly becomes an issue to everyone's privacy.

https://www.popsci.com/article/technology/scan-artist/

( https://web.archive.org/web/20190616105746/https://www.popsci.com/article/technology/scan-artist/ )

>Okay shazbot, what can we do about it?

I'm not sure yet, that's what I'm hoping our collective effort can discover. Below I will list some of the methods tried, there viability, cost, and feasibility.
